title: ollie family need support give it back campaign
story: THERE are now  – count them – MPs jostling to be our next Prime Minister, so there should be plenty of scope for smart policy pledges over the coming days and weeks.High on the to-do list for any future PM must be plugging the £million shortfall needed to support disabled children and their families — as demanded by The Sun in its brilliant Give It Back campaign.Making this relatively small investment will mean huge savings for the Treasury and the NHS in the future.It will also clearly prove we value our most vulnerable children, and the families who love them — which is surely how any decent politician seeks to be judged.These include families like that of Vickey Kowal, whose moving story was told in yesterday’s Sun.She is mum to seven-year-old Ollie, who suffers from a rare condition where he regularly stops breathing.Vickey and husband Adrian go to bed every night not knowingtheir son will still be alive in the morning. But the family does not get the support it needs.Thousands of kind-hearted Sun readers have already signed Vickey’s letter to Chancellor Philip Hammond demanding he properly funds services — such as respite and overnight support — for parents with disabled children.We hope more of you will show your backing by signing the letter today, because the Kowal family are not an isolated case.Mums and dads up and down the country feel unable to look after their disabled children adequately because they are so exhausted — and they are frustrated at being let down by a system that is meant to help them.When we surveyed parents, just four per cent said they felt they had the support to safely care for their child.More than half have been treated by a GP for depression, anxiety or stress.Ollies grandad Dave helps out when he can, but the family are far from an isolated case - they need your helpIndependent Provider of Special Education Advice- for specialist legal adviceNewle - a charity that provides help with equipmentGOV.UK - to understand your childs entitlementsNational Autistic Society And a huge  per cent of children have gone without therapies, such as physio and speech and language help, meant to improve their lives.This lack of support starts right from diagnosis — with parents being left alone to come to terms with devastating news.They are then left to care for children with complex needs — often through the night — for months or years without any help or respite.This care is often emotional and stressful, and sometimes physical and back-breaking, too.At my charity, Contact — which works with families of disabled children — we hear all the time from those who have to fight for even the most basic provision.Disabled children and their families are desperately struggling because of a lack of support.We want the Government to reinstate the £m of funding it has cut from early intervention services - such as respite care and vital equipment.It is time for the Government to Give It Back.The number of disabled children in the UK has risen to nearly  million over the past  years - up by a third.But funding and support has been cut.Families with some of the most vulnerable children in the country are struggling to cope.That’s why we’re working with the Disabled Children’s Partnership to help them.Together we can make a real dference and hugely improve the lives of disabled children and their families.We want you to share your stories, email us on giveitback@the-sunPlease sign Ollie’s letter to put pressure on the Government to act now.These families are morally — and legally — entitled to help from local authorities, but it is just not forthcoming.It does not need to be like this. All the families want is a little amount of support to enable them to care safely for their child at home.They want a chance to go shopping, a moment to catch up on sleep or have a bath, or time to spend with their other children.This is not about pity or sympathy for disabled children.The families we work with cherish every day spent with their children, who bring real joy and have so much to offer. Instead, we are calling on the Government to help tackle the problem of the lack of support they are given.I have worked in the field of disability for  years, so I know that services have never been perfect.But cuts to budgets, combined with a  per cent increase in the number of children classed as disabled over the past decade, means we have reached a critical point — one where we need to decide what kind of country we want to be.We are talking about some of the most vulnerable children in society, and also children who have the potential to contribute a lot.This is not a campaign based purely on emotion, compassion or wanting to do the right thing, although those are all important.There is a hard-headed economic case here, too. Without putting funding back into services for disabled children, we can guarantee the taxpayer will be faced with a bigger bill in the long-term.That is because when families break down, children can end up in care or needing expensive crisis intervention from local councils or the NHS.Our families are amazing. When the chips are down, people can be remarkable.But most do not want to be amazing, or superhuman — they want an ordinary le.As Sun readers, you can give families up and down the country a real shot at that.Sign Vickey’s letter using this link, and ask which of our potential leaders will be first to agree to Give It Back.Amanda Batten is chair of the Disabled Children’s Partnership, a coalition of  leading charities, and CEO of Contact.Jane Harris, Director of External Affairs at the National Autistic SocietyWe want as many people as possible to sign the open letter calling on the Government to give back the millions that have been cut from support for disabled children. Thanks to The Sun and The Sun readers for getting behind this important campaign.”Dr Hilary Cass OBE, Chair of BACDEvery professional working in the field of childhood disability will be grateful to The Sun for launching the Give it Back campaign.Naseem Waker, mum of Leila, sevenThe Give It Back campaign shows the stark reality of a very complex situation. I am delighted a paper with the clout of The Sun has taken up the cause. Dan White, writer and broadcaster, dad of Emily, It’s  and parents and children in our community are like ghosts to society. We live amongst you, breathe your air, look at the same stars, but you do not know us. Today, you must finally make the country aware.Tracy Williams, mum of HarryThis campaign can transform the lives of nearly a million families with disabled children. Thanks so much to the Sun for bringing our stories to light.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dimensions blind mum lifeguard birthday pool
story: Libby Hanley, , is registered blind and her eyes struggle to adjust when she takes off her glasses.The mum, of Staffordshire, was left mortied at Dimensions, run by Stoke-on-Trent City Council in Burslem, while celebrating her daughter Madison’s third birthday.She said: “I am registered blind and it takes a moment for my eyes to adjust to the light once I have removed my glasses.A member of staff at the swimming pool said you need to watch your child, so I replied and explained I couldnt see.She said, Well, I guess you shouldnt be here then.I felt so uncomfortable. She didnt call me to one side to say it.She said it in front of the whole pool.The mum is now calling for the staff to brush up on their equality and discrimination training.Libby was joined by family and friends who stood up for her when the comment about her disability was made on May .Terence Wildridge, , was one of the friends who was horried by what happened.He said: “My we Hollie works at the childrens centre in Biddulph and Libby goes there with her daughter Madison and we took them out to Dimensions.We went to the main reception and told them that Libby was registered blind.We took them into the toddlers pool under Hollies guidance.“Wed been in there for about  minutes. Everything was OK.Maddie was running around and then the female leguard said to Libby please look after your child.Terence marched to the changing room to collect Libby’s blind card to show to staff.He added: “The leguard just stuck her nose up at it.One of the parents said thats disgusting, love.They were trying to stick up for her because they could see how upset she was.We decided to get them out of the pool and take them back home.It should be investigated and staff retrained.Staff need to make sure they dont come out with that sort of thing again.We dont want another person to be affected like Libby was.Libby complained the pool’s management and she was offered a family two-for-one voucher for their next visit, which she says isn’t good enough.She said: “I am not interested in going there again.It made me feel quite emotional and made me question myself.The staff need more training. My disability is not a physical thing and its not an obvious disability.A city council spokesman said: We are aware of an incident that took place at Dimensions on May  and we are reviewing what happened.On the day, a member of staff spoke to the customer and she was informed about our official complaint process.We take all customer complaints seriously and address them as thoroughly as possible.

title: dakotas heroes d day fly again 75th anniversary celebrations
story: More than  vintage Douglas DC- and C- Skytrains - known as Dakotas - will take to the skies once more tomorrow and soar across the English Channel in formation.About  parachutists, in full Allied unorms, will be dropped into Sannerville, near Caen, where thousands of British paratroopers landed under cover of darkness in June , .The , soldiers that touched down  years ago paved the way for the largest seaborne invasion in history and the heroic efforts to liberate German-occupied France, and Europe, from the Nazi grip.The enormous operation involving almost , troops kick-started the Allied victory on the Western Front, which led to the end of World War II.It is that which is being commemorated by ious events throughout the country and the world this week.Two D-Day veterans -Harry Read, , and John Hutton,  - will make tandem jumps from Dakotas tomorrow.Great-great-grandfather Mr Read said the forthcoming descent - after which he will visit fallen comrades in cemeteries - will be tinged with sadness.Former Royal Signaller Harry, of Bournemouth, said: “In my heart I’ll be thinking of my mates.I have lived one of the most fulfilled lives that its possible for a person to live and they havent.Read more from D-Day veterans who remember the invasion:It was used heavily by the Allies during World War II and is still key for front-line service.A newly-added cargo door meant it was hugely useful for tranporting troops, cargo and the wounded.These planes were instrumental in carrying thousands of paratroopers over enemy lines in France as the D-Day landings began on June , .The Royal Air Force has dubbed this plane one of the most successful aircraft designs in history.The popular TV series Band of Brothers featured a US unit who were dropped into France from Dakotas.The th Troop Carrier Group carried members of the th PIR into Normandy, the story of which was retold in a powerful episode of the miniseries.Taking off from Duxford airfield, near Cambridge, the sky will be full of planes that have come from all over Europe, Canada, the US and Australia, to be part of the poignant tribute.The impressive and emotional display is set to be the largest gathering of Dakotas since World War II.It will mimic the Operation Neptune landings that took place more than seven decades ago and allowed the success of soldiers attempting to take back France by sea.The thousands of paratroopers that landed on enemy targets in Normandy in  protected the men on the beaches from German counter-attacks.And within five days , troops and , tons of supplies had managed to land on the beaches.The landings were followed by the -day Battle of Normandy, with a total of , Allied casualties including American, British and Canadian.Allied forces consisted primarily of American, British and Canadian troops but also included Australian, Belgian, Czech, Dutch, French, Greek, New Zealand, Norwegian, Rhodesian and Polish naval, air or ground support.TODAYNoon-pm, Poole, Dorset: The Royal British Legion ship MV Boudicca carrying D-Day veterans to Normandy will be in the harbour while Royal Marines demonstrate modern landing craft and assault weapons.TOMORROWam, Southsea Common, Ports-mouth: National Commemorative Event attended by the Queen, Prince Charles, President Trump, President Macron and Chancellor Merkel.The programme will include actor David Haig as Churchill plus Sheridan Smith performing music from the time. Actress Celia Imrie and Broadchurch’s Jonathan Bailey will also star. The Queen will thank the veterans on behalf of the  Allied nations.pm, Southsea Common, Ports-mouth: Flypast of  current and historic aircraft, including the Red Arrows, two Typhoons, a Spitfire and a Hurricane..pm-.pm: Formation Flight of Dakotas assembled from all over the globe will take off from Duxford airfield and head over Essex towards Eastbourne. They are expected to fly over Colchester at .pm and reach Southend at .pm.They will then fly past Maidstone in Kent at .pm, reaching Eastbourne at .pm.The aircraft will then continue to Le Havre in France and to the historic UK Drop Zone at Sannerville, Normandy.pm, Southsea Common Ports-mouth: Second Red Arrows display..pm, Portsmouth Port: Royal British Legion ship MV Boudicca to depart.pm-pm: Royal Navy ships will sail past the veterans on board MV Boudicca, see below. This is not expected to be visible from land but will be broadcast on TV.THURSDAYSATURDAY

title: d day veterans sail normandy beaches anniversary
story: More than  veterans boarded a ship chartered by the Royal British Legion ahead of the anniversary on Thursday.The Royal British Legion ship, left Dover on Sunday night at pm as part of the commemorations to mark the biggest amphibious invasion in history when some , ships took part in the initial push to liberate France during World War II.Before the ship set sail Dame Vera Lynn, , played a recorded message for those on board.She said: “It will be nostalgic and sure to bring back lots of memories.“Rest assured we will never forget what you all did for us.”Making a surprise appearance was Sir Rod Stewart and his we Penny Lancaster, who sang his hit Sailing for the vets before the ship sailed.The ship then arrived in Dunkirk where more than , Allied troops were evacuated in  before crossing back over the Channel to Poole harbour this morning.Theyto Portsmouth on Wednesday, where the Queen and US President Donald Trump will pay tribute to their bravery before heading back to France and the Normandy beaches.And on Thursday, June , the th anniversary of D-Day when , landed in France, they will meet Prince Charles at a ceremony in Bayeux.A Sea Cadets band played to Frederick Adamson, , from Coningsburgh, South Yorks, as he walked aboard with his grandson Philip Knight.Frederick, who served with the Kings Own Light Infantry. said: “What a wonderful reception. We certainly didn’t have a reception like that  years ago. It will bring back so many memories. ”Another of the veterans on the ship, John Roberts, , went on to become the captain of the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal.Later John, from Whitstable, Kent, became a Rear Admiral of the Fleet but during D-Day he was a Sub Lieutenant on HMS Serapis.He said: “On D-Day I watched from the deck as  planes and gliders filled the sky and dropped paratroopers into Normandy. I was a young sailor and never seen anything like it in my le.“It is important we never forget the sacrices that young men made in Normandy in .”Jim Docherty, , from Glasgow only told his family five months ago that had had even been at D-Day.He served as an -year-old Able Seaman on HMS Obedience, one of , ships involved in the campaign.His son John, , said: “It was only when Dad saw that the British Legion were taking veterans back to Normandy that he told us he had been there. We knew he had been on the Arctic Convoys but he had never mentioned D-Day. ”June ,  marks the th anniversary of the D-Day landings in Normandy when more than , servicemen began the push to liberate France.Ships gathered in the middle of the English Channel at point called Piccadilly Circus before making their way to the Normandy beaches.Paratroopers land behind enemy lines before the main assault begins with British soldiers tasked with securing the Benouville bridge on the Caen canal with Lieutenant Den Brotheridge leading the charge.He becomes the first Allied soldier to die in the assault when he is hit in the neck by machine gun fire.US paratroopers land with the aim of securing the town of Sainte Mere-Eglise, which is on the main road to Cherbourg which is the first French town to be liberated after hours of fighting.Allied warships start to open fire on the German sea defences with HMS Warspite firing off a broadside which marks the British and Canadian assault on Juno, Sword and Gold Beaches.US forces land on Utah and Omaha Beeches and come under fire from Nazi troops.By around midday commandos and troops finally reach the key bridges after heavy fighting to meet up with the paratroopers.Prime Minister Winston Churchill addresses the House of Commons.He tells MPs: “During the night and the early hours of this morning the first of the series of landings in force upon the European continent has taken place.”Sprightly Joseph Weaver, , a former Bombadier in the Royal Artillery who landed in Normandy three days after D-Day to man an ack ack battery, danced in the arrivals hall.He says: “I went back to Normandy to remember my fallen comrades for the th, the th and th anniversaries. I could not miss the th. We must never forget them.”Before Normandy he had manned guns trying to protect the city of Coventry against the German blitzkrieg.Tears in his eyes, Harry Cullen, , from Wigan, Lancs, raised a glass to his friends and comrades who did not .Harry, who served with the Royal Armoured Services Crops attached to the Canadian Army, said: “God bless those who didn’t . I’m nearly  years old and I think about those lads every day.“I’m not a great swimmer but I would have happily swum  miles back to Portsmouth to avoid the sights I saw.”Veterans also boarded a ferry in Portsmouth which was escorted into the Channel by Royal Navy vessels, the Type  frigate HMS St Albans and four P patrol vessels – HMS Puncher, Biter, Pursuer and Explorer.

title: deliberately drives car into girl
story: Steven Becky, , is said to have intentionally targeted the girl as she walked with her electric scooter through a residential neighbourhood near Salt Lake City, US.The car, a Volkswagen Jetta, hit a landscape boulder and flipped.Becky then ran up to the girl as she lay on a nearby front lawn and told her “We all have to die some time,” according to a witness cited in court documents.After the collision, Becky attempted to flee, but was restrained by a witness until police arrived, Fox News reported.He later told investigators he had hit the girl “because she was white”, and admitted to having been on Xanax, marijuana, LSD and psychedelic mushrooms at the time of the crash.“This is not what I would describe as veered into the gal or drted into the gal,” Police Chief John Eining told reporters, according to Deseret News.“My description would be turned into the gal.”Officers at the scene said Becky had been “uncooperative, aggressive, and non-sympathetic toward the child victim”, according to a report released by the Draper Police Department on Saturday.The child, who has not been named, suffered a serious head injury and a fractured hip.Chief Eining said that she had been wearing a helmet at the time of the collision, and that it had probably stopped her from suffering more serious injuries.“We believe that probably had something to do with the condition she’s in now,” he said.After the crash, Becky was taken to hospital and then Utah County Jail, where he was booked on charges of attempted criminal homicide and driving under the influence with serious bodily injury.

title: duterte gay cure philippines president
story: The strongman leader, , also invited four ladies on stage to smooch him in a bizarre speech to members of the Filipino community in Japan last Thursday.He attacked his rival Senator Antonio Trillanes IV saying that he was “similar” to him because they were both homosexual.But the former mayor of Manila, known for his controversial remarks and hardline policies, said he had been “cured” by having relationships with women.He said that he “became a man again” when he married his first partner Elizabeth Zimmerman, according to CNN.Duterte continued with his offensive diatribe saying that a gay person had told him that Trillanes liked men based on the way he “moved”, reports Rappler.He said: “I said, ‘Are you sure ’ They said, ‘You ask any gay person who sees Trillanes move, theyll say hes gay.’ No wonder. Good thing Trillanes and I are similar. But I cured myself.”Speaking of his first marriage, he added: “When I began a relationship with Zimmerman, I said, this is it. I became a man again.”Elizabeth Zimmerman, , married the controversial politician in  before they split in  after having two kids together.Duterte’s girlfriend Honeylet Avanceña, , was sitting behind him when he invited four women on to the stage to kiss him on the cheek.The Filipino leader also kissed one of the ladies on the lips.He told the women he was looking for an older unmarried female to kiss, saying: “First you shouldnt be married okay. Second you are not a minor. You maam. You want a smooch “Those four come here. Let them come up. Let them in.”This is not the first time the outspoken president has used slurs which are offensive to the LGBT community while attacking his political opponents.In , he called the US ambassador to the Philippines a gay son of a bitch prompting US officials to complain to their counterparts in Manila.However, his statements on gay marriage and homosexuality are conflicting.He has previously said that the bible should recognise LGBT people.Yet in , he declared that marriage should only be between a man and a woman months before he said he thought the law should be changed to allow same-sex unions.Danton Remoto, leader of Filipino LGBT political party Ladlad, said Duterte’s comments change depending on his audience.He told the New York Times: “Duterte’s remarks are slippery like mercury.“His opinion depends on the audience.”But gay rights activist Rhadem Camlian Morados slammed the president’s statements calling them “demeaning.”He said: “His gay joke was very counterproductive and demeaning” adding  “asthere’s a need to ‘pray the gay away’ and that homosexuality is a disease that needs to be cured.”

title: tory chiefs change leadership rules to knock out no hope candidates
story: And anyone failing to secure the backing of at least  MPs will be knocked out after the first round.The powerful  backbench committee voted through the changes today in a desperate attempt to fast-track the election of a new leader.Senior Tories were worried the huge number of candidates –  as of this morning – may have delayed the leadership contest beyond the summer break.Under the rule change, MPs wanting to stand will need a proposer, seconder and at least  other Tories signed up.To move beyond the first ballot, candidates will need to win  per cent of the vote –  MPs.To progress beyond the second one, they will need  per cent of the party to back them –  MPs.The -name threshold would currently exclude Mark Harper, Kit Malthouse, Esther McVey, Rory Stewart, Andrea Leadsom .But all the current frontrunners including Boris Johnson, Jeremy Hunt, Michael Gove, Dominic Raab and Sajid Javid would be able to stand.Earlier today James Cleverly pulled out of the race saying he didnt have enough support - but blamed his Tory colleagues for not being willing to accept an outside.Yesterday Tories demanded others drop out to stop the contest dragging on.James Brokenshire said the race was a shambles and there were too many running.Boris Johnson is the current frontrunner and has the most support from MPs so far.But Michael Gove and Dominic Raab are closing in behind him too.The PM will officially step down as Tory leader and kickstart the contest on Friday.

title: colourised pics india 125 years ago
story: The images, captured by American photographer William Henry Jackson, show everyday le under the British Raj, which lasted from  to  and covered most of the Indian subcontinent.They were taken in  on black and white lantern slides as part of the World’s Transportation Commission, an American expedition organised by railroad magnate Joseph Pangborn.The expedition was launched to gather information about transport systems in countries around the world, but Jackson also took opportunity to document the lives of ordinary people.The shots show workers rowing a thatch-roofed boat along a wide river, crowds boarding a train while a vendor sells food on the , and two European women being taken for a ride on an elephant.Also depicted is Pangborn being carried on the backs of four Indian porters.The scenes of everyday le include two huntsmen holding their rles before a hunt, a group of small children sitting in the midday sun, and buskers holding stringed instruments.As well as India, the Commission travelled round most the world between  and . It visited more than  countries, including Britain, Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Egypt, Turkey, Australia, China, Korea, Japan, Russia, almost every country in South America, and modern-day Sri Lanka, Thailand, and Indonesia.Jackson ed from the trip in  with over  photographs.He later became a partner in publishing company Detroit Photographic Company, and began to experiment colourising his photographs using techniques only then being developed.His photos are now part of a collection held by the U.S. Library of Congress.

title: change uk loses more than half its mps after pro eu party flops in polls and tears itself apart
story: Just  days after their launch. six of the breakaway partys MPs - including the interim leader Heidi Allen - chose to quit the group today after weeks of troubles, gaffes and in-fighting.Sources claimed Ms Allen – a former Tory – recommended last week that the party should dissolve after their disastrous European Election results.But in heated make-or-break talks yesterday, ex-Tory Anna Soubry and former Labour MP Chris Leslie insisted they would keep going.In a statement, Ms Allen said that by “ing to sit as independents we will be best placed to work cross party”.The anti-Brexit movement said they will now sit in Parliament as independent MPs, but theres speculation they could now join with the Liberal Democrats.One source said they were convinced that Ms Allen and fellow ex-Tory Sarah Wollaston had already received offers to join themTories Ms Allen and Sarah Wollaston also walked out after rows behind the scenes, but Anna Soubry stayed behind and took the reigns up as leader of the remaining  MPs.Luciana Berger – another to quit – is understood to have held talks about a ‘non-aggression pact’ with Lib Dems in her Liverpool Wavertree constituency.They said in a joint statement today the priority for the beleaguered party must be to provide collegiate leadership to bring people together in the national interest.Furious new leader Ms Soubry said earlier: Im deeply disappointed that at such a crucial time in British politics our former colleagues have made this decision.Now is not the time to walk away, but instead to roll up our sleeves and stand up for the sensible mainstream centre ground.And in a thinly veiled dig at Ms Allen, Mike Gapes – an ex-Labour MP who is also staying on – said: “Those of us with political experience knew we’d be in this for the long haul.”Chuka Umunna – a former Labour Shadow Business Secretary - immediately launched a new website under ‘The Alternative’.He said: “The Remain forces need to work even more closely together.“We need to regroup and consolidate activity to maximise our impact.”In March a group of Labour MPs left over Jeremy Corbyn and the partys failure to tackle anti-Semitism, and three Tories quit to fight for a second referendum.But the party have made a series of huge errors and ended up polling just . per cent in the European elections and not getting a single MEP elected.And at the time Ms Soubry attacked Ms Allen for the bizarre idea that people should vote tactically for the Lib Dems in some parts of the UK.Remainers the Lib Dems did much better and swept up many more people who wanted a second referendum.After todays split they were urging the leftover Change UK MPs to come over and join them.Lib Dem leadership hopeful said earlier: Change UK’s swt demise shows that my reluctance from the beginning to discuss mergers and pacts, and to hold firm in our belief that the Liberal Democrats are the clear home for all who want to stop Brexit, was the right call.Anyone who signs up to our core liberal values of liberty, equality and community would be welcome to the newly invigorated Liberal Democrats.The collapse completes a farcical three months for a party that vowed to “crush” the Lib Dems and become the clear centrist threat to the Tories and Labour when they launched.There was confusion over branding as the party went from being called the “Tiggers” – the Independent Group – to Change UK.As the polls turned against the new party, MEP candidate Rachel Johnson joked she appeared to have joined a “sinking ship”.Insiders said the split showed that some – such as Mr Leslie and Ms Soubry – had long-held dferences with the Lib Dems on issues such as security and law and order.

title: family kids orphaned house blaze
story: Him Gurung was left fighting for his le after leaping from the window of the family home  cradling his daughter as his we lay inside.Hospital cleaner Ranjana Gurung, , died in the flames at their property in Orpington, South East London, last Monday night.Now police have said her husband Him, also , passed away on Sunday.Their children had to jump from a first-floor window in a dramatic bid for safety with their brave father.Neighbours watched on in shock as they heard the son screaming help me, help me.One resident saw Him receiving oxygen from paramedics before he was taken to hospital in a critical condition.Detectives and fire chiefs are investigating how the fire at the Nepalese familys £, terraced house was started.Scotland Yard said yesterday that a preliminary cause of death for Ranjana was given as burns and inhalation of fire fumes.Their children were taken to hospital with non le-threatening injuries and have since been discharged.In a statement issued today, the Met confirmed a -year-old man had died in the blaze.A post-mortem examination held on Thursday gave the preliminary cause of death as burns and inhalation of fire fumes.The two children were taken to hospital with non le-threatening injuries and have since been discharged.No arrests have yet been made.Ranjana and Him had been living in the UK for around  years, and moved into the property in .The sister of Ranjana, Yam, paid tribute to a very caring mother, saying it was incredibly painful to lose her.The front windows of the property had been left open with curtains tied up on the ground floor after the blaze.There was slight charring around the windows but no major damage on the outside, and neighbours said the back of the house suffered worse.She worked at the Princess Royal University Hospital in Orpington.

title: kim jong un mass games north korea criticism
story: The murderous despot attended the lavish opening of the Mass Games alongside his sister Kim Yo-jong who made her first public appearance in nearly two months.Despite a vast number of dancers and gymnasts taking part in the highly coordinated show in the May Day Stadium in capital Pyongyang – it has since been revealed that Kim was unhappy with the event.It is not clear whether the strongman leader will carry out executions as a result of his disapproval of the opening ceremony.The states news agency KCNA said the dictator “called creators of the performance and seriously criticised them for their wrong spirit of creation and irresponsible work attitude, pointing to the contents and forms of works”.He said that performers “have a very important duty in socialist cultural construction” it was reported.The colourful event is a huge propaganda exercise detailing the history of the rogue state and depicting modern le in the crackpot country.Kim watched the performance along with his we Ri Sol-ju, his sister and other high-ranking Korean officials in the , seat stadium.Images from the event shown on South Korean television showed one of the dictators senior advisers with his head in his hands during the ceremony.North Korea expert Minyoung Lee told the BBC that the despot’s criticism is not unusual.She said: “Kim Jong-un publicly criticises departments and poor work performance.”Ms Lee added that Kim’s criticisms can range from events such as the games to trees supposedly being planted incorrectly.However, the North Korean leader has been on a blood-soaked purge following the failure of his summit in Hanoi with Donald Trump.Agricultural official Hwang Min was executed with an anti-aircraft gun after he challenged Kim’s leadership in .O Sang-hon, the deputy minister for public security was accused of corruption in  and was tied to a stake then burned alive with a flamethrower.Kim’s aunt, Kim Kyong-hui, was poisoned after she protested the death of her husband in the same year.The rotund despot also had his older brother, Kim Jong-nam, bumped off while he was in Malaysia using a deadly nerve agent.A manager of a turtle farm in the country was shot when the corpulent dictator visited the farm after he explained that the reptiles had died due to a lack of power, water and food.According to reports, Kim executed five aides after his meeting with the US President ended without a deal.The tyrant is said to have ordered a firing squad to kill Kim Hyok-Chol and four of his underlings amid claims they sold information to the Americans.Kims bloody revenge on his Vietnam summit negotiating team was revealed by South Koreas Chosun Ilbo newspaper.A North Korean source said: Kim Hyok-Chol was investigated and executed at Mirim Airport with four foreign ministry officials in March.The newspaper claims Kims purge is designed to ert attention from discontent within the pariah state.But it didnt end there, with other officials packed off to North Koreas infamous death camps.Co-negotiator Kim Sung-Hye and translator Shin Hye-Young were among those sent to prison. Hye-Young is said to have done nothing wrong apart from making a translation error.In February, it was claimed Kim made his own uncle Jang Song-thaek watch his workmates get ripped apart by anti-aircraft guns during a string of sickening executions.Defector Kang Cheol-Hwan said he was told by those who witnessed the bloodshed that two men who worked with Kims relative were obliterated by the over-the-top firing squad.The luckless pair were allegedly targeted by eight massive anti-aircraft guns after having lumps of iron placed into their mouths by Kims cronies.Kims uncle was killed later that same year reportedly by the same method after branding him a traitor.

title: wild west cowboys unseen pics sale
story: The historical images were taken by a British farm worker and show le on the ranches of Colorado and New Mexico in the US in the s.One dramatic picture captures the thrilling moment a group of cowboys ride towards the camera with hats held aloft.The unnamed Brit photographer would have documented his travel experience using these images which he collated into an album he brought back to the UK.The snaps have been put up for sale from the deceased estate of a private collector from Surrey.They will go under the hammer with Flints Auctions, of Reading, Berks, who expect them to fetch £.While the bulk of the images are believed to have been taken by the farmhand, the album also contains  larger prints by a professional photographer of the era, W.A White.There are pictures of cattle ranching and farming, as well as snaps of a cattle round up and bustling street scenes in Taos, Santa Fe on San Geronimo day, a religious celebration.In addition, there are breathtaking pictures of the Spanish Peaks in Colorado which the Ute Indians named Huajatolla, which translates as the breasts of the Earth.Keith Petts, director at Flints Auctions, said: These are wonderful early images of cowboys and it is quite rare to find this breadth of images documenting every day le on the ranches at the time.It was not until the s that amateur photography really took off in the US.The album has been consigned from the family of a deceased estate of a collector of cameras and photos.It is possible that a British man went over from Surrey in the late s to work on the ranches in America and kept this photographic record, bringing it back with him at some point.The historic American cowboy, immortalised in Wild West films, arose from the vaquero – or cattle driver - traditions of northern Mexico.The sale takes place on June .

title: steve baker join tory leadership contest
story: And he is expected to say thatBoris Johnson and other leading Eurosceptic contenders don’t back his proposals – he will stand himself.Sources claimed the self-styled Brexit ‘Spartan’ has been preparing a bid for weeks.One of the Tory contenders told The Sun: “Steve is setting the bar too high purposely, so he can run himself.“His plan is a one way ticket to No Deal.He’ll have  members of theERG thatMark Francois will whip up for him and then he’ll get knocked out.”Challenged, the former Brexit Minister refused to comment on his own ambitions.But he said: “This is a major national crisis.“Conservative MPs need to understand that the Conservative Party will be obliterated by the Brexit Partythey don’t satisfy our voters who have defected. This is the time to put a stake in the ground.”Allies of Mr Baker insisted that he still hadn’t decidedhe would stand.One said: “He’s going to leave himself a bit of wriggle room.”But his new plan – backed by  Eurosceptic Tories – comes just days before nominations for the contest close.And it is thought the document - demanding a “clean, managed Brexit” – has already been circulated around some leadership contenders’ camps.Under the plan, Mr Baker says the UK should be prepared to leave without a formal deal in place, and trade on WTO terms before a free trade agreement can be struck.He adds that ‘alternative arrangements’ can be used to ensure a seamless border on Ireland – and “practical contingency arrangements” enforced to cover issues such as aviation.And he insists Britain withholds the £ billion orce bill – instead applying a “substantial part” on tax cuts and to help businesses adapt to a No Deal.Mr Baker writes: “The new Prime Minister will have around three months further to prepare the United Kingdom to leave the European Union.“It is vital they enter office with a clear and deliverable plan.“This document presents the necessary plan. It is recommended the new Prime Minister should adopt the following proposals as the basis for Government policy.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: india rubbish mountain taj mahal environment
story: The fetid dump in Ghazipur, New Delhi, occupies the space of  football pitches and is home to hundreds of stray cows, dogs and rats who are seen wandering the stinking expanse.If it continues to grow at its current rate it will be taller than the iconic ft high Taj in Agra.Last year Indias Supreme Court warned that red warning lights will even have to adorn the dump to alert passing planes.Ghazipur opened in  and reached its capacity in  - but New Delhi sources say , tonnes of garbage are still being dumped there each day.Ahead of World Environment Day tomorrow, dozens of rag pickers could be seen scouring the rancid dump to salvage recyclable materials.But theres a long way to go. In  two people were killed after a section of the rubbish dumps collapsed in heavy rains.There are also fears the landfill has polluted the air and groundwater due to the toxic gases and liquid oozing from the pit, including methane belching from the rubbish.Fires sparked by methane gas also regularly break out, taking days to extinguish.Chitra Mukherjee, head of Chintan, an environment advocacy group said: “It all needs to be stopped as the continuous dumping has severely polluted the air and ground water.”Residents have been left struggling to breathe from the momentous dump.“The poisonous smell has made our lives hell. People fall ill all the time, -year-old local Puneet Sharma told the Times of India.Local doctor Kumud Gupta said she sees about  people, including babies, each day mostly suffering from respiratory and stomach ailments caused by polluted air, the Post reports.A government survey conducted between  and  reported that Delhi saw  deaths from acute respiratory infection while more than . million residents suffered from infections.Seven of the worlds  worst polluted cities are in India, with New Delhi ranked the worlds most polluted capital, a study published by AirVisual and Greenpeace showed.India, along with a number of other mainly Asian nations, was forced to take up the slack after China banned plastic imports - but then banned plastic waste and scrap in March this year.The country has vowed to completely phase out single-use plastics by .India has a low per-capital plastic consumption of kg a year - which is ten times as low as some other western countries.Prime Minister Narendra Modi launched Operation Clean India when he took power in , and has since had tens of thousands of public toilets built and introduced new waste management rules.However, watchdogs have repeatedly accused Delhis authorities of not taking the waste crisis seriously, the Times of India reports.Low per-capita plastic consumption of just kg compared to western countries where up to  times that is consumed each year, but disposal is main problem.Earlier this year India banned imports of waste plastic in a bid to close the gap between waste generation and recycling capacity.It has also committed to completely phasing out single-use plastics by .

title: bgt alesha dixon final hand fart performer
story: “Is that it ” “Seriously ” “ grand ” “For one of that lot ”Never was it more true than the th and most sentimental series yet of Britain’s Got Talent, where the major talking point of last week’s live shows should’ve been Simon Cowell’s hair, which had been dyed a vivid shade of gorilla haemorrhoid black for the occasion.One David Walliams barb and a death stare from the boss, though, made it clear the subject was very much “off limits”.And Cowell probably had a point, as well.He knows that unless the judges act like the most credulous, gushing, “upped-your-game” morons in the theatre, then the whole show unravels.Nothing new there, obviously. It’s been like that since series one.It’s just that this year’s contestants forced them to be even more credulous, gushing and moronic than usual.Particularly the magicians, who were all doing iations on the same trick, with such little stagecraft, that one of last year’s rejects, Marc Spelmann, was deemed best of the bunch by virtue of putting on his X mask and saying nothing.It didn’t end there, however.Critical faculties also had to be suspended for a procession of try-hard comedians, pub singers, sob stories, village fete dancers and that Haunting thing which had Amanda Holden gasping, panting, yelping “F***” and Simon claiming: “It sounded like being next door to you on honeymoon.”Though probably not the fortnight inside Les Dennis’s static caravan in Rhyl.It wasn’t all bad, naturally.Someone almost held a tune, I’m sure, and there was a bit more tension to Jonathan Goodwin’s “Blindfold chick- en with crossbow”than there was about the Gomonov bird, who kept ducking out of the way almost every time her mate threw a kne.But what BGT really needs in such circumstances are dingbats like Gonzo, the fat Japanese tambourine frenzy, and Guy First, the Israeli bloke who can hand-fart the opening verse and chorus of We Will Rock You.He was born to be on this show, in fact, which makes what Alesha Dixon did during his semi-final appearance even more of a sackable offence. She buzzed him.She actually buzzed State Of The Fart, claiming he was “funny”, but she was “thinking rationally”.A very bad idea. Think rationally, Alesha, luv, and you might as well pack up and go home now, because the nut-fudge fringe acts are one of only two reasons this carnival of the mediocre is still going after  series.The other, of course, is the hosts, Ant  Dec, who may have fluffed the odd line but they never gushed or patronised, let alone talked down to the eventual winner, Colin Thackery.It was a majestic performance that came with a slightly unwelcome sting in the tail, on Sunday night, from Ant.“There’s a very special new show coming up later in the year, Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions. The finest acts from the last  years will compete against the best acts from around the world.” Dec: “Have they got a host yet ”Sell every share in the project immediately,ITV hasn’t got them both nailed down on five-year contracts. INCIDENTALLY,you watch only two shows this week, make them tonight’s finale of Chernobyl, on Sky Atlantic, at pm, and Harry Hill’s Alien Fun Capsule, Saturday, ITV, .pm, which features Oscar-nominated actor Sir Tom Courtenay playing “Michael Rodwell – blow ya top,” with Les Dennis.Gary Neville: “Both City and Liverpool have won  games, Liverpool ten games.”And Neil Mellor: “I wouldn’t say it was luck, but Spurs were certainly fortunate.”AND the  Soap Award for Most Hastily Arranged Holiday goes to . . .EastEnders’ Sharon Mitchell, who’d bought her tickets, sorted her visa, packed and headed off for Heathrow within  seconds of having the idea to go to Australia, last year.Just one of the many amazing storylines not honoured at the st Awards, hosted by Phillip Schofield, in Manchester, which someone on the red carpet described as a “Very Hollywood” occasion.Yeah, very. Even , to the best of my knowledge, The Oscars has never had a Best Bitch category.It’s no longer part of these ITV awards, sadly, and the ceremony’s gone all worthy, making the usual disapproving noises about sexism, championing mental health campaigns and acknowledging Hollyoaks’ Jack Reynolds, who’s set to become the oldest soap star ever, at , beating the previous record set by Corrie’s Bev Callard, who’s about .In another break with tradition, the Soap Awards had the chance to honour a genuinely brilliant episode of EastEnders, Shaki’s funeral, which movingly combined the character’s death with real-le victims of kne crime.I need hardly tell you, then, it lost the Scene of the Year category to an entirely forgettable Gail monologue from Coronation Street.The biggest missed opportunity of the night, however, possibly came with the “very special” gong for a member of the Emmerdale family.“She’s a faultless pro. . . one of the show’s finest ambassadors. . .  paved the way for female colleagues. So the Tony Warren award goes to. . .”Roxanne Pallett for Celebrity Bi. . .“Val Lawson.”Oh, OK. Maybe next year then HIGHLIGHT of the television week was arguably Gwyneth Paltrow’s spirit guide, Shaman Durek, attempting to perform “a healing process” on This Morning’s host Eamonn Holmes.Not a one-man job, by any stretch of the ­imagination.After a brief bit of finger clicking and some new-age waffle, though, Eamonn was sedated and Durek was commanding the spirits to “go into the access point in his stomach”, before asking: “Is there anything the spirits need ”Is there ever, Durek.Spirits, would you like a JCB Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Lavinia Woodward, , attacked lover Thomas Fairclough after drinking at her university accommodation at Christ Church college. She was given a ten month prison term suspended for  months at Oxford Crown Court after admitting unlawful wounding. But Woodward was spared prison after the judge said she was too bright and being locked up could harm her career as a heart surgeon.   The university said she would face a disciplinary he chose to . She had suspended her studies but would have been able tothis September at the earliest. But Woodward has now formally withdrawn from Oxford, student news site The Tab reports. Woodward stabbed Mr Fairclough in the leg with a bread kne and threw objects at him in a drunken attack on December , . The treasurer for Christ Church, Laviniaaposs college, said: Ms Woodward has formally withdrawn from the college and the university. Woodward was a high-flying Oxford student and her research on lipoproteins and vein grafts had been published in journals.    Mr Fairclough tried to stop her from drinking and she became increasingly volatile. She discovered he had Skyped her mum to figure out what to do, flew into a rage and started throwing objects around. He called  and Lavinia stabbed him with the bread kne - injuring his leg and fingers. Emergency services arrived to find Lavinia, intoxicated, deeply distraught and mentally disturbed. She planned to turn the kne on herself before Mr Fairclough disarmed her.    After sentencing, Woodward was living in a million pound Kensington flat with her boyfriend, the son of a Russian billionaire, waiting for it all to blow over so she couldto Oxford. An unnamed friend said Lavinia was lying low and biding her time. They said at the time: I think they would be happy to have her back, and that she will end up ing quietly. Sheaposs done some very interesting work in cardiology, theyaposve described her as a future Nobel Prize winner.

title: conservatives reveal new pm announced
story: NewsConservatives reveal when new PM will be announced and change election rulesAfter complaints that the field in the contest was getting too crowded, the party has confirmed it will make it tougher for people without support to stay in the contestShareByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsWe now know when the next Prime Minister will be announced "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Conservative Party has revealed that the next Prime Minister will be announced in the week beginning July nd. It comes as the party announced signicant changes to the rules on how they will select their new leader. The revised rules were brought in after party grandees worried that the race, which until yesterday featured  candidates, would drag on and on plunging the country into yet more constitutional chaos. In a joint statement, Tory chairman Brandon Lewis and the acting joint chairs of the  Committee Cheryl Gillan and Charles Walker said: Candidates will be required to submit a nomination including a proposer, a seconder and six other Members of Parliament supporting their candidacy. Ballots of MPs will then be held over the course of the following two weeks.    After the first ballot, any candidate receiving  votes or fewer will be eliminated. After the second ballot, any candidate receiving  votes or fewer will be eliminated. If the ballot thresholds are met by all candidates, then the candidate with the lowest number of votes will be eliminated. Balloting will continue until two candidates remain. How the vote will workA call for candidates will be made at pm on Friday  June . Nominations will be received from am Monday   June and will close at pm on the same day. Candidates will be required to submit a nomination including a proposer, a seconder and six other Members of Parliament supporting their candidacy. Ballots of MPs will then be held over the course of the following two weeks. After the first ballot, any candidate receiving sixteen votes or fewer will be eliminated. After the second ballot, any candidate receiving thirty two votes or fewer will be eliminated.If the ballot thresholds are met by all candidates, then the candidate with the lowest number of votes will be eliminated. Balloting will continue until two candidates remain.The first ballot will take place on Thursday  June, from am to pm. Further ballots are scheduled for  June,  June and  June.The Rt Hon Dame Cheryl Gillan MP and Charles Walker OBE MP will act as ing officers for the election.

title: excruciating moment theresa explain question
story: NewsExcruciating moment Theresa May has to explain question to Donald TrumpThe President was asked about a future trade deal between the UK and the US - and it seems like either he didnt hear or he didnt understandShareCommentsByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video theresa-explain-question-trump-says-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May was forced to explain a question to the most powerful man on Earth - in a moment that is sure to leave people on both sides of the Atlantic squirming. The US President was asked by a reporterthe NHS should be on the table in any future trade deal - a position supported by his Ambassador but opposed by the British government. But Donald Trump appears to not understand or mishear and begins answering.Then, a clearly flustered Theresa May steps away from her podium and explains the issue to the President.   President Trump said: I think we’re going to have a great trade deal, yes. I think we’re going to have a great, comprehensive trade deal. A reporter asked: “With the NHS  Should the NHS be on the table, Sir ” Mrs May is then heard telling the President: He says should the National Health Service be on the table. Trump said: “Look, I think everything with a trade deal is on the table. When you’re dealing with trade, everything is on the table. “So NHS or anything . There are a lot more than that. So everything will be on the table. Absolutely.”     Just minutes later Health Secretary and Tory leadership contender Matt Hancock hit out at Mr Trump. He tweeted: Dear Mr President. The NHS isn’t on the table in trade talks - and never will be. Not on my watch.Earlier, Jeremy Corbyn told a protest against the Presidentaposs visit that Labour would fight with every last breath to save the NHS from the clutches of US healthcare firms.We’re in the midst of a debate about the future of the relationship between Britain and Europe and the rest of the world. The basis of that debate should surely be that we encourage the protection of jobs and living standards and public services and reach out to people all across the world. But it should not be a debate about how we go forward with no deal at the same time as offering up our precious, wonderful National Health Service to private American companies to come in and take it over. We will not stand for that. We will fight with every last breath of our body to defend the principle of a healthcare system free at the point of need for everybody as a human right.

title: liam fox refuses rule out
story: NewsLiam Fox refuses to rule out US companies having access to NHS in post-Brexit trade dealMr Fox said he would protect the NHS but that the exact details of what regulations would be in the future would be for inidual future governments to decideShareCommentsByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsLiam Fox made the comments in an interview with LBC "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailInternational Trade Secretary Liam Fox has refused to rule out that any post-Brexit trade deal with USA would give private American healthcare companies access to the NHS. Dr Fox said that while he would protect the NHS in a trade deal, the exact details of what regulations would be in the future was something for inidual governments to decide. Speaking to LBC, the Tory Minister said: One of the main exemptions that exist in trade agreements is for governments to regulate their own public services and what it tends to say, notwithstanding anything in this agreement. Governments have absolute right to regulate their own public services and in our case,the NHS, and that wouldn’t change. You would imagine that would be a standard provision in any treaty as it was for example in the treaty that we just negotiated with Canada.  He also restated his support for protecting the NHS as current government policy. Earlier he tweeted: I have consistently been clear that we will protect the @NHSuk as part of any future trade agreement.But pushed onthat meant that the NHS would be a no go zone for private companies, Dr Fox said it would be something for each inidual future government to decide. Dr Fox said: Well the government would determine, the government of the day of whatever party would determine exactly what the regulations were round the NHS. What you would not have would be any interference with the NHS unless the government of the day wanted it to be so and that’s how it should be. It should be that governments have the right to regulate their own public services in the national interest.  But later Dr Fox issued a statement doubling down on his commitment to protect the NHS for as long as he is in office.He said: “The government has consistently been clear: the NHS is not for sale to the private sector, and never will be.As a doctor who trained and worked in the NHS, I am committed to ensuring that no trade agreements will ever be able to alter these fundamental facts.” Speaking to protesters outside Parliament yesterday Jeremy Corbyn says he will aposfight with every last breathapos to save the NHS from the clutches of US healthcare firms. But Dr Fox  criticised Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn for not attending the state dinner with Donald Trump. He said: He should have been there, this was not just a political visit, this was a state visit, where the President was here as a guest of the United Kingdom, he was there as a guest of her Majesty the Queen last night. It was a celebration of the sacrices that were made, and of course we are seeing the D-Day celebrations over the next few days, it was a celebration of the sacrices we have made together to protect our freedom and our democracy, and it’s a shame that you had a leader of the Labour Party who seemed to go out of this way to want to insult the President of the United States. A Labour Leader who doesn’t believe in maintaining nuclear weapons for the State, you do wonder what it is he is actually committed to.    The International Trade secretary described Ivanka Trump, who he sat next to at the dinner as an extremely intelligent, charming, pleasant and well-informed dinner partner. But in controversial remarks, Dr Fox said he sided with Mr Trump in a long-running dispute with London Mayor Sadiq Khan . In the past, Mr Trump has challenged Mr Khan to an IQ test and been critical of his response to the London Bridge attack in . Before landing Mr Trump tweeted: Sadiq Khan, who by all accounts has done a terrible job as Mayor of London, has been foolishly aposnastyapos to the visiting President of the United States, by far the most important ally of the United Kingdom. He is a stone-cold loser who should focus on crime in London, not me. Kahn [sic] reminds me very much of our very dumb and incompetent Mayor of NYC, de Blasio, who has also done a terrible job - only half his height. In any event, I look forward to being a great friend to the United Kingdom and am looking very much forward to my visit. Landing now. A spokesman for Mr Khan said the childish insults should be beneath the president of the United States. But Mr Fox said he sided with President Trump in the dispute. He said: I think it was very ill-advised of the Mayor of London to say that the red carpet should not be rolled out for the Leader of the free world, for the President of our closest ally, the United States, a country which is a guarantor of our security, a country which is our single biggest trading partner and which is our biggest investment relationship in the world. I think was really beneath the dignity of an elected official in the UK.

title: dad jihadi jack would never
story: NewsDad of Jihadi Jack would never forgive himselfson died and he did nothingThe parents from Oxfordshire are facing charges of funding terrorism after sending cash to Jack in a bid to get him home from the ISIS stronghold in Raqqa, SyriaShareByKelly-Ann Mills:,  JUN NewsJack Letts, dubbed Jihadi Jack, posted photos online from Syria "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe father of aposJihadi Jackapos dad told a court he would never forgive himselfhis son died in the Middle East and he did nothing to protect him. John Letts claimed he was told by the police that no court in the land would convict him for helping his son get out of the war-torn region. The -year-old and his we Sally Lane, , are accused of funding terrorism by sending cash to their -year-old son Jack Letts while he was living in the ISIS stronghold of Raqqa in Syria. But their lawyers say counter-terrorism police had given the parents from Oxfordshire the aposgreen lightapos to send money to their radicalised son. In a police interview on January ,  , Letts told to detective constable Michael Neath that he told his son to give himself up to the British.  He said: In the meantime, you know you canapost sleep, this is the son that you nurtured, and itaposs horrible. It is like the greatest, the only useful thing I ever did in my le was having two children and one of them is right there.The interview between Letts and DC Neath ran for an hour and a half after he had been arrested on suspicion of breaching terrorism legislation. Wearing a green fleece and glasses, he explained his sense of joy when he was told by police, he was free to send funds to his son. But police told Lane and Letts the information they had been given on December  was wrong and they could not send money to their son. He explained: So I went to bed that night and I thought we were going to talk about it the next day, although I was clearly minded to get it to him because Iaposll never forgive myselfI donapost save Jackaposs le when I have the chance to do it. And you know, I didnapost know she was sending it but on the other hand I needed to help Jack out, so I supported the concept. The prosecution allege Lane and Letts jointly attempted to send £, to their son between September  and January . title: d day hero 93 whoops
story: NewsD-Day hero, , whoops with delight on adrenaline-pumping ride  years onA group of  Normandy veterans have gathered together in Poole, Dorset to meet their modern day equivalentsShareCommentsByRachael Bletchly:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video -year-old-d-day-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAlbert Evans hangs on to his beret and whoops as the Royal Marine RIB bounces across the waves in high-speed donut turns. “What a ride! How fantastic!” yells the old soldier, , the wind carrying away his excited cries. Perched in the stern, two young marines watch admiringly as the pensioner from Dudley, West Midlands, takes the adrenaline-pumping ride in his stride. But Albert doesn’t scare easily. And nor do the  other  to -year-olds watching from the quayside and ship decks.    Seventy five years ago they dodged bullets, bombs and U-boat torpedoes as they stormed the coast of Normandy to turn the tide of the Second World War. And today, as they sailed into the peaceful waters of Poole Harbour, this spirited band of brothers got a heroes’ welcome from today’s naval personnel. The Royal British Legion-chartered MV Boudicca, which had sailed overnight from Dunkirk, was escorted into dock by three marine vessels as local children waved from the quayside. After disembarking the veterans and their carers chatted to young service-men and inspected their modern kit. Then Albert, who saw his Bren gunner pal Ernest being shot and killed in front of him in the weeks after D-Day, joined a handful of others taking thrilling boat rides.    On the quay former Royal Marine Commando Eric Carter, , of Birmingham, climbed up into an armoured vehicle. Serving Marine Christopher Takacs of Charlie Company,  Commando, demonstrated a new grenade machine gun that fires  rounds a minute. He said: “They’re our forefathers and we look up to them. They laid the ­foundations of what we are today ­especially in the D-Day landings.”” Impressed Mr Carter, who landed on Juno beach with Canadian troops on D-Day, said: “They weren’t like this in my day. It’s a nice piece of kit.” Coxswains of  Assault Group’s  Assault Squadron and troops also showed off their kit before sharing stories with the D-Day heroes. Veteran Trevor Stacey, Royal Marine of  Commando, chatted happily. Albert Barnes, , of Southend, Essex, inspected a modern weapon’s sights.  Royal Marines veteran Robert William Yaxley, , said: “I feel so lucky to be here. I landed on D-Day and went through to Germany without a scratch.It’s very important to mark this.” Aboard the Boudicca, Gordon Highlander veteran James Glennie, , of Aberdeen, tried a modern assault gun. The veterans are on a week long cruise marking the anniversary and will be in Portsmouth today for the official commemoration attended by the Queen and President Trump.    On Thursday they drop anchor off Gold Beach, Normandy, for services at Bayeux’s Cathedral and War Cem­etery and a march-past in Arromanches. Arthur Jones, , of ­Wolverhampton, drove a Sherman tank on to Gold Beach as he served with the th Essex Yeomanry. He said: “Another of our tanks had been blown up. The men hadn’t made it so I didn’t know what lay in store. I made it through though.” Eyes welling up, he added: “I think I’m going to get emotional standing in the cemetery at Bayeux on Thursday with the chaps who didn’t come home.” Arthur Bailey, , served with the th West Riding Infantry Division on D-Day then with the Paras at the Battle of Arnhem in September . He spoke to two local schoolchildren fascinated by his chest-full of medals. Explaining what they were for, he told the girls: “A lot of men died in the war, there aren’t many of us left.”    He went on: “It’s lovely that they are showing an interest. Youngsters today don’t seem to know much about it. Perhaps this will spark new interest.” Jack Mortimer, , from Leeds also made friends with a group of pupils. Jack, a dispatch driver with the th Ordnance Beach Detachment, had transported ammunition and mortars in his jeep on D-Day. But yesterday he stood surrounded by youngsters jigging away as they showed him the moves for toothless Grandpa Shark in the Baby Shark dance. He beamed: “Oh, how marvellous. I’ll have to remember this one.”    He added: “Today has been brilliant. I can’t really get the words out. It’s just tremendous to be welcomed like this.” Back on the Boudicca the veterans enjoyed a talk from TV historian Peter Snow and were entertained by magician Lance Corporal Richard Jones, winner of Britain’s Got Talent in . L Cpl Jones, , who serves with the Household Cavalry, said: “This is a really wonderful event to be a part of. “It is incredible and awe-inspiring to hear what these men went through on D-Day and throughout the war. “They are clearly having a great time, making new friendships and renewing old ones and having a real laugh together.

title: distraught man called doctor 21
story: NewsDistraught man called doctor  times with no answer before jumping from clfPaul Connell suffered from anxiety and depression and had seen a counsellor the day before his death but was not referred to the mental health servicesShareCommentsByStian AlexanderBrendan McFadden:,  JUN NewsMr Connell suffered with anxiety and depression"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A man called his doctor  times without getting answer before jumping off a -ft high clf to his death, an inquest heard.Paul Connell jumped from clfs in Ramsgate, Kent, on March  this year. The -year-old, who suffered from anxiety and depression, had seen a counsellor on March , but was not referred to the mental health services, the coroneraposs court heard. Mobile phone records examined by the coroner found that despite the repeated calls to his GP on the morning of his death, he had not been able to speak to anyone.    Canterbury Coroneraposs Court heard last week how a note found in his pocket read aposVoices in my head. Iaposm sorry. Love you all xapos. The court heard how Mr Connell had been travelling with his we in Asia last  year and had suffered from altitude sickness as the base camp of Mount Everest. The coroner heard how Mr Connell texted his mum Donna Ayres, saying he wanted to aposthrow himself off the mountainapos and he was airlted off the peak for hospital treatment. He ed to the UK in February after several months in Asia and was seen by doctors at the Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother Hospital in Margate, Kent. Mr Connell was given anti-depressants and sleeping pills, but he was not referred to specialists mental health specialists, the court heard. The coroner heard from his GP at Newington Road Surgery in Ramsgate, Dr Adem Akyol, who said Mr Connell had suffered from apospanic attacks, anxiety and depressionapos.    He told the court that he had seen Mr Connell on March  - just over two weeks before his death - and that his mental health problems were aposprobably retrospective of a longer term medical problemapos. Detective Sergeant Paul Deslandes, of Kent Police, told the inquest that two dog walkers saw Mr Connell lying aposface down on the beachapos under the clfs at around am on March . He said: Thereaposs no formal path to the clf face. I formed the opinion that he had jumped from the clf. He said that messages on Mr Connellaposs phone did not indicate that he was having apossuicidal thoughtsapos, but said: He was going through a dficult part of his le and had a history of mental health problems. His mental health deteriorated over a short period of time. Recording a verdict of suicide, Coroner James Dillon said: The evidence is clear that Paul would’ve deliberately made his way through and climbed over a wall or fence and I can take the view he did take his own le. A note was found in his pocket which shows his intent and I can record a death of suicide.Mum Donna Ayres, speaking to the Kent Messenger newspaper after the inquest last week, said that mental health wasnapost taken aposseriously enoughapos. She said: There was nothing physically wrong with him - they did all the tests. There was something mentally wrong and they sent him home for me and his we and friends to look after because there was no place for him to go. He was doing everything right. He was going running, eating and not drinking caffeine or alcohol, and did everything they told him to do. But it was when the two teenagers were preparing for le at dferent universities that an upset Jeremy told a teacher, who was a priest, about his feelings.  He was told his behaviour was sinful and the following day he was sent to the headmaster and given an ultimatum - be expelled from school just four weeks before his A Levels, or go to his GP and ask for treatment for his homosexuality. I was so stunned, I donapost think I was on this planet. But he became resigned to the therapy and endured two sessions every week.  Jeremy was brought up a strict Catholic in Keighley, Yorkshire, by his parents Bert and Betty. He had three brothers, Donald, Neil and Alistair and any mention of sex was forbidden. There are no words that can repair the damage done to anyone who has ever been deemed aposmentally unwellapos simply for loving a person of the same sex, says Prof Wendy Burn, of the Royal College. For those who were apostreatedapos, the trauma of such experiences can never be erased. But for Jeremy, the damage had already been done. He said: Iaposve always berated myself for breaking down and telling someone I was gay because of the pain it caused. For decades afterwards, Jeremy suffered from black moods and had psychotherapy. Jeremy had many dferent treatments for his depression and was ultimately diagnosed with posttraumatic stress disorder . But it was not until , when he had cognitive behavioural therapy, that he began to make progress. In , he started eye-movement desensitisation and reprocessing therapy , a treatment which helps PTSD sufferers connect memories in their brain which have been fragmented by trauma. Jeremy said: It made a world of dference to me. I used to have flashbacks to the aversion therapy, and unexplained jolting pains. But after  months of EMDR, the pains and flashbacks slowly disappeared. It was amazing. Jeremy has finally come to terms with what happened and feels he can now be honest about his sexuality. If thereaposs one thing I want people to take away from my story, itaposs that le can go on after terrible things happen, he says.
